regretList.regret: I changed my believe about marriage and children. Today, I am divorcing and I am am other of three children.
I regret the choices that I made in my undergraduate and graduate years studying. I wish that I had chosen a career path where there was more potential for a higher salary and respect.

Not stepping up when my girlfriend Robin Wheeler got pregnant.  I still love her and that was almost 40 years ago.  I didn’t know what was going on but i torpedoed our relationship because it was long distance and I couldn’t handle it.

My senior year in college (at a small college), the football coach who was a family friend invited me to go out for the football team so I could have the life experience of being on a football team. He said that I likely wouldn't play much at all, but would experience the camaraderie and culture of "football." I didn't do it--and regret it to this day, decades later.

I regret not leaving my job sooner and moving to Florida instead of, subconsciously, allowing the workplace bully to steal my soul for more than a decade longer. I would have retained, maybe, even enhanced my enthusiastic and confident self instead of slowly becoming a hoarding, isolated hermit. I miss spontaneous solo or with-friends adventures; I miss not having anything to say about a weekend or a vacation from work.
I regret not taking my life as seriously as I should have when I was younger. Now I feel I’m running out of time to make something of myself.

I wasn't focused on academic or athletic achievement in high school. I wish I had worked harder in my teens, instead of doing drugs and getting into trouble.
I regret not being willing to give time and energy to something I find insignificant to satisfy my supervisor, as this has resulted in my lack of career advancement.

Not learning earlier in my life that I would be diagnosed with complex ptsd from not being nurtured or cared for as a kid and understanding how that would effect my relationships, especially my romantic ones. I'm 44 and have been trying to love and earn love so hard and it's left me without a family and giving so much to non vulnerable, unhappy people. I've done so well for myself without really any guidance from my family. But I am lonely in a sense. I so wish I learned more and trusted my gut more when I was 29. So much so. I know I'm young, but I want my own tribe/family.

I regret that my work affected me very deeply, and I attempted to take my life. This incident resulted in alienating my children, one that is completely estranged from me, and destroyed my marriage. I hadn’t communicated well about what was so emotionally overpowering. My younger daughter and ex-husband have never spoken to me again. I am now 70 and I long to have some form of a decent relationship with my children.

The biggest regret I have is abruptly breaking up with my boyfriend in University, and then rather spitefully having sex with another guy a few weeks later. 

This happened in 1990, when we were both 20. I was immature and impulsive, and at the time I was full of selfish justifications that I have since realized were ridiculous. The truth of how wrong and hurtful I had been eventually sank in, but it was too late to undo the pain I caused. R was a good, sweet, kind, and loving man, the love of my life actually, and I betrayed him. 

If I had a time machine, this would be the ONE turning point in my life that I would go back to, where I would make a whole set of entirely different choices based on knowing what I know now. This one action completely and permanently changed the courses of both our lives, and has had repercussions to this day, more than 30 years later.

I was visiting a friend whose husband had recently died. She was in deep grief and revealed she was piling on the blankets at night to try to stay warm without him beside her in their bed. I immediately thought the warmth and coziness of a down (duvet) quilt might help her feel a bit safer and bring her some comfort but convinced myself I didn't have time to go shopping before I had to go home (to a different city). But the reality was that duvets were expensive back then and I didn't want to spend the money. But there was time. I should have made the time. And 35 years later I see that life has provided for me financially. So in the end, the money would have been okay too. She was a good friend. Today I try to make bolder gestures of comfort and kindness when I make them.
